Nier: Automata isn't the flawless masterpiece that a lot of people seem to claim it is, but it is a damn good 9/10 for me. Most of its problems lie in the fact that its combat and exploration are frankly boring as hell, but the story, world building, and characters are insanely good.

It starts off by wasting the player's time with meaningless fetch quests and "go here, kill x" quests, and I have no idea why these could be here other than because of some boneheaded executive's decision to pad out the game's length. They shouldn't have ever been included and the game suffers for their existence. The game does a lot of similar stuff throughout playthroughs that feels like it exists to artificially extend playtime, and I was not a fan of it considering how middling the actual gameplay can often be.

What all of this means is that you end up with an okay game with a story that takes too long to ramp up, and I think a lot of people will ultimately drop the game before it "gets good". Okay. This game is exceptional, truly outstanding, worth playing if you have interest in experiencing the best of video-gaming, there's no experience quite like this one, but... with a fairly heavy caveat (and one or two more minor ones). Let me break it down like this.

Route A - 8/10
Route B - 1/10
Everything after - 10/10

Unfortunately, the game rolls credits after Route A, so it's easy to feel like it's a pretty good experience and little else will come from restarting a run. Route B I feel definitely should have been edited down. I personally pushed through the drag of this against my better judgement. The structure of the game in this way definitely leaves something to be desired - it could have just been one story that split off into two with the 9S/A2 section in the second half, imo. Credits rolls a few times and there is a title card drop somewhere in the middle of the game, for some reason. I think around when the tower appears during Route C/D.

The crafting/economy/upgrades area of things is also quite weak. In regular play, I don't think I got enough for one upgrade for my pods the entire time, and maybe only one or two for the starting sword. It's not a game that lends itself to knowing where this or that stripped screw or rusted bolt or whatever is farmed, it all blends into one. Economically, as it's skewed toward healing being too cheap, the game is generally on the easier side, because you can always just use a medium recovery for 50% of your health back, and they cost you fairly little in the context of the game. Fish are also probably too good a source of dollarydoos. I was only killed a few times in my playthrough, when an outlier enemy who hit for way too much would suddenly catch you twice in the space of one second - outside of that, nothing posed too much of a threat. They didn't really plan for deaths and how much that would set you back it seems, because it sometimes puts you back several minutes of running across the map - because sometimes they grey out a certain location you can teleport to, because reasons. read: because the devs want to railroad you.)

I will also quickly say that the game is a bit ham-fisted/inelegant/a little on the nose with its conveyance of the themes of machines having consciousness and sentience and such. Sometimes it feels a little like it could have been handled with more care when storyboarding the game. But in equal measure, there are truly profound moments that balance those out plenty, and make the game a really worthy experience.

Onto the good:
-The character design, world design, architecture, etc in the visual department, all pretty amazing. 2B and A2 are pretty heavily sexualised in their models, a bit distracting, but it is what it is.
-The game is pretty 'anime' in it's setpiece design. Meaning, DBZ, or something - i dunno, i'm not huge on anime. But there's big setpieces and mechs and stuff. It's cool.
-The audio - music and sfx - is pretty excellent. You'll know it as soon as you get to the resistance camp. One of the female vocalists who sings in the forest kingdom area is like... whiny sounding though? A bit grating. Other than that, it's a 9 or 10/10 OST. Not the kind of thing you'll be playing in everyday life much, but serves its purpose in the game exceptionally
-The voice acting and writing also is generally really, really good. 
-The shot direction is often great
-The character animations particularly in combat, although I find the combat from a gameplay perspective to be a bit lacking. Fun if you like hack and slash stuff, but I personally like a bit more of a balanced challenge like a dark souls game, where there's measurements of time between swings and windows and such. This just felt like mindlessly pressing the slash button sometimes. And 9S' hacking combat wears thin fairly fast as well. A really great spin on a hacking mini game, but yeah, wears thin if the entire combat experience is just hacking mini games (in Route B, and C/D, whichever is 9S')

The game does some really cool things like having a 'boss' be beaten by not attacking and the ending credits thing - taking the one currency the player has put into the game, their time, and asking if they'll trade it to the aid of others, without thanks.

Anyway, this is poorly formatted and whatever, but this game starts good, gets bad, and then gets great. Basically that's it. If you're interested in anime, or hack and slash stuff, or philosophy, or the best video games have to offer, then i'd put this one on the list. It's a bit of a drag at times, but I promise the second half of the game is a pretty epic time. Had it all been tightened up to that same standard, it would be an easy 9 or 10/10 game for me, despite the combat being kind of lacking in actual balance and challenge. As it stands, I can only rank the three main sections of the game, A, B, and C/D/E, seperately as I did at the start. Definitely a true accomplishment in the realm of videogames, but not without fault. Still, play this game. Honestly, if you haven't played games and wanted one to get a sense of what they can be capable of, this might be a good single game to play. Great stuff, PlatinumGames.

So many people love this game and I don't understand why. It's flashy, but I had to stop playing after 1/3 the way through. I can't recommend it for the following reasons:

1) the game is level gated, not skill gated.

If you're level 35 and up against level 45 enemies, you'll get thromped. Come back at level 45 and you'll dominate. Perhaps that's as it should be. But why does it happen? Your HP, armor, and damage output hasn't changed THAT much. Your tactics haven't changed. Only your level has. The game appears to artificially cap your real damage by some factor differential between your level and your enemy level. The only reason that level 45 enemy was so tough at level 35 was because you nerfed my damage. I'm not hitting 10x harder at level 45.

2) the game doesn't respect your time. 

There's a LOT of backtracking and rehashing the same areas. New quests are presented that force you to go back to the same areas over and over and over again. Many quests are multi-stage, but they require time to pass between completing one stage and starting the next. That means, you guessed it, you have to leave and come back. Once I even found boxes containing "useless" items that I couldn't pick up. I told myself, "If I have to come back here to get this %#$ later because a quest needs this item I'm gonna be very upset. Yes, that immediately happened.

3) formulaic plot: 

Lots of pseudo-philosophical gibberish on the meaning of life and free will, etc. can a machine be alive, etc. I've heard from those who have completed that game that it's a great plot and maybe it is when done, but I just can't see it happening.
